Topics.Strand: Theme 1: Introduction to markets and market failure

Sub_topics.description: Thinking like an economist: understand the process of developing models in economics, including why economists make simplifying assumptions when modelling real-world behaviour.

Understand and use the ceteris paribus assumption (“all other things equal”) when building and interpreting economic models; recognise how changing one variable while holding others constant supports causal reasoning in economics.

Understand why economics cannot usually run controlled scientific experiments in the way natural sciences can (e.g., ethical/practical constraints, complex interacting variables), and the implications for testing economic models.
Distinguish between positive economic statements (testable/descriptive claims) and normative economic statements (value-based/prescriptive claims).

Understand the role of value judgements (normative preferences) in influencing economic decision making and government policy choices; recognise how different objectives/ideologies can lead to different policy conclusions.
Understand the economic problem arising from scarcity: unlimited wants alongside finite resources, requiring choices about allocation.
Distinguish between renewable resources and non-renewable resources and understand their relevance to scarcity and sustainability.
Understand opportunity cost as the value of the next best alternative forgone; apply to decisions by consumers, producers (firms), and government.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: PPF uses (productive potential, opportunity cost, efficiency, growth)
Sub_topics.description: Use production possibility frontiers (PPFs) to depict: (i) maximum productive potential of an economy; (ii) opportunity cost using marginal analysis; (iii) economic growth or decline; (iv) efficient vs inefficient allocation of resources; (v) possible vs unobtainable production combinations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Movements along vs shifts of the PPF
Sub_topics.description: Distinguish between movements along a PPF (reallocation of resources) and shifts of the PPF (changes in productive capacity). Explain possible causes of shifts (e.g., changes in quantity/quality of factors of production, technology, productivity).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Capital vs consumer goods on a PPF
Sub_topics.description: Distinguish between capital goods and consumer goods; interpret PPFs that trade off capital vs consumer goods and link to future productive capacity and economic growth.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Specialisation and division of labour (Adam Smith)
Sub_topics.description: Understand specialisation and the division of labour in organising production, with reference to Adam Smith’s ideas.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Pros and cons of specialisation and division of labour
Sub_topics.description: Analyse advantages and disadvantages of specialisation and division of labour in organising production (e.g., productivity gains vs monotony, deskilling, dependence).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Pros and cons of specialisation for trade
Sub_topics.description: Analyse advantages and disadvantages of specialising in producing goods and services to trade (e.g., comparative advantage gains vs overdependence, exposure to shocks).
Understand the functions of money: medium of exchange, measure of value (unit of account), store of value, and method of deferred payment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Economic systems: free market, mixed, command (Smith, Hayek, Marx)
Sub_topics.description: Distinguish between free market, mixed and command economies; understand associated viewpoints with reference to Adam Smith, Friedrich Hayek and Karl Marx.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evaluation of free market vs command economies
Sub_topics.description: Analyse advantages and disadvantages of a free market economy and a command economy (e.g., efficiency/incentives vs equity/planning; market failure vs government failure).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Role of the state in a mixed economy
Sub_topics.description: Understand the role of the state in a mixed economy (e.g., provision of public goods, regulation, redistribution, stabilisation), combining market mechanisms with government intervention.

Topics.Strand: Theme 1: Introduction to markets and market failure

Sub_topics.description: Understand the underlying assumptions of rational economic decision making: consumers aim to maximise utility and firms aim to maximise profits.
Distinguish between movements along a demand curve (price changes) and shifts of a demand curve (changes in non-price determinants).

Understand factors causing a shift in the demand curve (conditions of demand), e.g., income, tastes/preferences, prices of substitutes/complements, population/demographics, advertising, interest rates/credit, expectations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Diminishing marginal utility and demand curve shape
Sub_topics.description: Understand diminishing marginal utility and explain how it influences the downward slope/shape of the demand curve.
Understand the meaning of price elasticity of demand (PED), income elasticity of demand (YED), and cross elasticity of demand (XED) as measures of responsiveness of quantity demanded.
Use formulae to calculate PED, YED and XED (e.g., %ΔQd/%ΔP; %ΔQd/%ΔY; %ΔQd/%ΔPx).
Interpret numerical PED values: unitary elastic, perfectly elastic, relatively elastic, perfectly inelastic, relatively inelastic; relate magnitude/sign to responsiveness.
Interpret numerical YED values: inferior (negative), normal (positive), luxury (YED>1); distinguish relatively elastic vs relatively inelastic income responsiveness.
Interpret numerical XED values: substitutes (positive), complementary goods (negative), unrelated goods (≈0).
Analyse factors influencing elasticities of demand (e.g., availability of substitutes, necessity vs luxury, proportion of income, time period, brand loyalty, habit, addictive goods).
Use demand elasticities to analyse effects and incidence of indirect taxes and subsidies on consumers/producers and government revenue/cost.
Use YED to analyse how changes in real income affect demand for inferior/normal/luxury goods and implications for firms/government.
Use XED to analyse how changes in prices of substitutes and complements affect demand in related markets, and implications for firms/government.
Explain and calculate the relationship between PED and total revenue (TR=P×Q): when demand is elastic/inelastic/unitary and the effect of price changes on TR.
Distinguish between movements along a supply curve (price changes) and shifts of a supply curve (changes in non-price determinants).

Understand factors causing a shift in the supply curve (conditions of supply), e.g., costs of production, technology/productivity, indirect taxes/subsidies, number of firms, prices of related goods, expectations, weather (primary sector), exchange rates (imported inputs).
Understand price elasticity of supply (PES) as responsiveness of quantity supplied to a change in price.
Use the formula to calculate PES (e.g., %ΔQs/%ΔP).
Interpret numerical PES values: perfectly elastic, relatively elastic, perfectly inelastic, relatively inelastic.
Analyse factors influencing PES (e.g., spare capacity, stock levels, time to adjust, mobility of factors, ability to store, complexity of production).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Short run vs long run and PES
Sub_topics.description: Distinguish between short run and long run in economics and explain why supply is typically more elastic in the long run; apply to PES analysis.
Define and determine equilibrium price and equilibrium quantity where demand equals supply.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Excess demand and excess supply diagrams
Sub_topics.description: Use supply-and-demand diagrams to depict excess demand (shortage) and excess supply (surplus).
Explain how market forces (price adjustments) eliminate excess demand and excess supply and restore equilibrium.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Shifts in supply/demand and new equilibrium
Sub_topics.description: Use supply-and-demand diagrams to show how shifts in demand and/or supply change equilibrium price and quantity in real-world contexts.
Understand functions of the price mechanism in allocating resources: rationing, incentive, and signalling.
Apply the price mechanism to different market contexts (local, national, global), recognising how prices coordinate resource allocation across markets.
Distinguish between consumer surplus and producer surplus and relate them to willingness to pay and willingness to accept.
Use supply and demand diagrams to illustrate and measure consumer surplus and producer surplus areas.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: How shifts affect consumer and producer surplus
Sub_topics.description: Analyse how changes (shifts) in supply and demand affect consumer surplus and producer surplus (distribution of welfare between consumers and producers).
Using supply and demand analysis and elasticities, analyse the impact of indirect taxes on consumers, producers and government; determine tax incidence (burden split) and represent on diagrams.

Using supply and demand analysis and elasticities, analyse the impact of subsidies on consumers, producers and government; identify on diagrams the areas representing producer subsidy and consumer subsidy.
Explain why consumers may not behave rationally due to the influence of other people’s behaviour (e.g., herd effects, network effects, status/positional consumption).
Explain why consumers may not behave rationally because of habitual behaviour (habit persistence, addiction, brand loyalty) and implications for demand/elasticity.
Explain why consumers may not behave rationally due to weakness at computation (bounded rationality, limited information processing, heuristics/biases).

Topics.Strand: Theme 1: Introduction to markets and market failure

Sub_topics.description: Understand market failure as when the free market mechanism leads to an inefficient allocation of resources (often where social welfare is not maximised).
Identify and distinguish types of market failure: externalities, under-provision of public goods, and information gaps.
Distinguish between private costs, external costs and social costs; use relationships such as social cost = private cost + external cost.
Distinguish between private benefits, external benefits and social benefits; use relationships such as social benefit = private benefit + external benefit.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Negative production externalities (MSC/MSB diagram, welfare loss)
Sub_topics.description: Use a diagram with marginal analysis to illustrate external costs of production (e.g., MPC, MSC) showing the difference between market equilibrium and the social optimum; identify the welfare loss (deadweight loss) area.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Positive consumption externalities (MSB/MPB diagram, welfare gain)
Sub_topics.description: Use a diagram with marginal analysis to illustrate external benefits of consumption (e.g., MPB, MSB) showing the difference between market equilibrium and the social optimum; identify the welfare gain (deadweight) area from under-consumption.
Analyse impacts of externalities on economic agents and evaluate government intervention in various markets to internalise externalities (link to taxes, subsidies, regulation, permits, information).
Distinguish between public and private goods using non-rivalry and non-excludability; apply to examples.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Free rider problem and under-provision of public goods
Sub_topics.description: Explain why public goods may not be provided by the private sector due to the free rider problem and inability to exclude non-payers, leading to under-provision.
Distinguish between symmetric information and asymmetric information in markets.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Imperfect information and misallocation of resources
Sub_topics.description: Explain how imperfect market information/information gaps can lead to misallocation of resources (e.g., consumers making suboptimal choices, adverse selection, moral hazard links).

Topics.Strand: Theme 1: Introduction to markets and market failure

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Indirect taxes (ad valorem and specific) to address market failure
Sub_topics.description: Understand and use diagrams to analyse government intervention via indirect taxation to correct market failure, including ad valorem (percentage) and specific (per unit) taxes; evaluate effects on price, quantity, welfare, and incidence.
Understand and use diagrams to analyse subsidies as intervention to correct market failure; evaluate effects on price, output, welfare, government spending, and distribution of benefits.

Understand and use diagrams to analyse maximum prices (price ceilings) and minimum prices (price floors) as interventions; explain consequences such as shortages/surpluses, black markets, and welfare effects.
Understand tradeable pollution permits as a market-based method to reduce negative externalities; explain how permits create incentives and can lead to a desired level of emissions.
Understand state provision (and funding) of public goods as a response to under-provision by the private sector; evaluate benefits and potential issues.
Understand government provision of information to reduce information gaps (e.g., labelling, public health campaigns) and improve resource allocation.
Understand regulation as intervention to correct market failure (e.g., standards, bans, licensing) and evaluate effectiveness and unintended consequences.
Understand government failure as intervention that results in a net welfare loss (i.e., policy makes outcomes worse than the market outcome).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Government failure: distortion of price signals
Sub_topics.description: Explain how interventions can distort price signals, leading to inefficient allocation and welfare loss.
Explain how intervention may have unintended consequences (e.g., black markets, regulatory avoidance, perverse incentives) that reduce welfare.
Explain how excessive administrative/monitoring/enforcement costs can cause government failure and reduce net welfare gains from intervention.
Explain how government information gaps (imperfect knowledge of costs/benefits, preferences, externalities) can lead to poor policy design and government failure.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Examples of government failure in markets
Sub_topics.description: Apply government failure concepts to various markets; analyse why specific interventions might lead to net welfare loss in context.

Topics.Strand: Theme 2: The UK economy – performance and policies

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Real GDP growth as economic growth
Sub_topics.description: Understand rates of change of real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) as a measure of economic growth; interpret growth rates over time.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Real vs nominal; total vs per capita; value vs volume
Sub_topics.description: Distinguish between: real and nominal measures; total and per capita measures; value and volume measures, particularly in national income statistics.
Understand other national income measures, specifically Gross National Income (GNI), and how it differs from GDP (e.g., net factor income from abroad).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Comparing growth between countries and over time
Sub_topics.description: Compare rates of economic growth between countries and over time; interpret reasons for differences using appropriate context/data.
Understand Purchasing Power Parities (PPPs) and use PPP-adjusted figures for international comparisons of output/income and living standards.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Limitations of GDP for living standards comparisons
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate limitations of using GDP to compare living standards between countries and over time (e.g., distribution, non-market activity, externalities, leisure, quality of goods/services).
Understand national happiness/wellbeing measures, including UK national wellbeing; analyse relationship between real incomes and subjective happiness (e.g., diminishing marginal utility of income).
Define and distinguish inflation, deflation, and disinflation.
Understand the process of calculating the UK inflation rate using the Consumer Prices Index (CPI) (basket of goods, weights, index calculation conceptually).
Evaluate limitations of CPI in measuring inflation (e.g., representativeness, substitution bias, quality changes, housing costs).
Understand the Retail Prices Index (RPI) as an alternative measure of inflation and broad differences from CPI.
Analyse causes of inflation: demand-pull inflation, cost-push inflation, and growth of the money supply.

Analyse effects of inflation on consumers, firms, government and workers (e.g., real incomes, uncertainty, menu/shoe-leather costs, competitiveness, fiscal drag, redistribution between debtors/creditors).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Unemployment measures: claimant count vs ILO/LFS
Sub_topics.description: Understand measures of unemployment: the claimant count and the International Labour Organisation (ILO) measure via the UK Labour Force Survey (LFS).
Distinguish between unemployment and under-employment (e.g., working fewer hours than desired / overqualified).
Understand significance of changes in employment, unemployment and inactivity rates; interpret labour market data and participation.
Analyse causes of unemployment: structural, frictional, seasonal, demand-deficient/cyclical, and real wage inflexibility.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Migration, skills and labour market outcomes
Sub_topics.description: Analyse significance of migration and skills for employment and unemployment (e.g., skill shortages, labour supply, structural mismatch).
Analyse effects of unemployment on consumers, firms, workers, government and society (e.g., lost output, fiscal costs, inequality, health/social issues, hysteresis).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Balance of payments components (current account, trade in goods/services)
Sub_topics.description: Understand components of the balance of payments with particular reference to the current account and the balance of trade in goods and services.
Define and interpret current account deficits and current account surpluses; link to trade balances and income flows.
Analyse relationship between current account imbalances and other macroeconomic objectives (growth, inflation, employment, exchange rate stability).
Understand interconnectedness of economies through international trade and how shocks transmit via trade and financial linkages.

Topics.Strand: Theme 2: The UK economy – performance and policies

Sub_topics.description: Understand aggregate demand components: AD = C + I + G + (X − M).
Understand the relative importance of AD components (C, I, G, X−M) and how this can differ over time/in different economies (UK context).
Understand the aggregate demand (AD) curve and why it is downward sloping in AD/AS analysis.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Movement along vs shift of AD
Sub_topics.description: Distinguish between a movement along the AD curve (change in price level affecting real output demanded) and a shift of the AD curve (change in components of AD).
Understand disposable income (Yd) and how changes in disposable income influence consumer spending (consumption, C).
Understand the relationship between savings and consumption (e.g., higher saving implies lower consumption ceteris paribus).
Analyse other influences on consumer spending: interest rates, consumer confidence, and wealth effects (e.g., housing/asset prices).
Distinguish between gross investment and net investment (accounting for depreciation).

Analyse influences on investment (I): rate of economic growth, business expectations/confidence, Keynes ‘animal spirits’, demand for exports, interest rates, access to credit, and influence of government/regulations.
Analyse main influences on government expenditure (G): the trade cycle and fiscal policy decisions.
Analyse main influences on the (net) trade balance (X−M): real income, exchange rates, state of world economy, degree of protectionism, and non-price factors (quality, branding, reliability).

Topics.Strand: Theme 2: The UK economy – performance and policies

Sub_topics.description: Understand the aggregate supply (AS) curve and its role in the AD/AS model.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Movement along vs shift of AS
Sub_topics.description: Distinguish between movement along the AS curve and shifts of the AS curve; relate to changes in price level vs changes in supply conditions.
Understand the relationship between short-run aggregate supply (SRAS) and long-run aggregate supply (LRAS).
Analyse factors influencing SRAS: changes in costs of raw materials and energy, exchange rate changes (imported input costs), and changes in tax rates (cost effects).
Understand different shapes of the LRAS curve: Keynesian and classical; explain implications for output and price level responses.
Analyse factors influencing LRAS: technological advances, changes in relative productivity, education and skills, government regulations, demographic change and migration, and competition policy.

Topics.Strand: Theme 2: The UK economy – performance and policies

Sub_topics.description: Understand and use the circular flow of income model showing flows between households and firms and the role of injections/withdrawals.
Distinguish between income (flow) and wealth (stock) and apply to economic analysis.
Analyse the impact of injections into and withdrawals from the circular flow of income (e.g., I, G, X as injections; S, T, M as withdrawals) on the level of national income/output.
Understand the concept of equilibrium real national output (where planned injections equal planned withdrawals / AD equals output).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: AD/AS shifts and equilibrium output/price level
Sub_topics.description: Use AD/AS diagrams to show how shifts in AD or AS cause changes in equilibrium real national output and the equilibrium price level.
Understand the multiplier ratio as the relationship between an initial change in injections (e.g., ΔI, ΔG, ΔX) and the total change in national income/output (ΔY).
Understand the multiplier process (re-spending chain) by which an initial increase in injections leads to successive rounds of income and consumption increases.
Analyse effects of the multiplier on the economy (e.g., amplified changes in GDP/output, employment, inflationary pressure, imports, fiscal position).
Understand marginal propensities and their effects on the multiplier: marginal propensity to consume (MPC), save (MPS), tax (MPT), import (MPM); link to leakages (withdrawals) and injections.
Calculate the multiplier using formulae: 1/(1−MPC) and 1/MPW where MPW = MPS + MPT + MPM; apply to numerical contexts.
Understand the significance of the multiplier for shifts in aggregate demand (AD): how changes in injections/propensities affect the magnitude of AD shifts and output changes.

Topics.Strand: Theme 2: The UK economy – performance and policies

Sub_topics.description: Analyse factors that could cause economic growth (e.g., increases in factors of production, productivity improvements, technological progress, investment, human capital).
Distinguish between actual growth (short-run increases in real output) and potential growth (long-run increases in productive capacity/LRAS).
Understand the importance of international trade for (export-led) economic growth; analyse how increased exports can raise AD, productivity, and economies of scale.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Actual growth rates vs long-term trend
Sub_topics.description: Distinguish between short-run/actual growth rates and long-term trend growth rates; interpret deviations from trend.
Understand positive and negative output gaps (spare capacity/overheating) and difficulties of measurement (estimating potential output, data revisions).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: AD/AS diagram of an output gap
Sub_topics.description: Use an AD/AS diagram to illustrate an output gap (level of spare capacity) in an economy.
Understand the trade (business) cycle as fluctuations in economic activity around trend growth; identify phases.
Understand characteristics of a boom (rapid growth, high confidence, rising inflationary pressure, low unemployment, possible asset bubbles).
Understand characteristics of a recession (falling output for consecutive periods, rising unemployment, low confidence, disinflation/deflation risk).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Costs and benefits of economic growth
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate benefits and costs of economic growth and impacts on consumers, firms, government, and current/future living standards (e.g., incomes, public services vs externalities, inequality, sustainability).

Topics.Strand: Theme 2: The UK economy – performance and policies

Sub_topics.description: Understand economic growth as a macroeconomic objective and how it may be measured/assessed in policy terms.
Understand low unemployment as a macroeconomic objective and its importance for living standards and public finances.
Understand low and stable inflation as a macroeconomic objective and reasons for prioritising price stability.
Understand balance of payments equilibrium on the current account as a macroeconomic objective and reasons it may matter.
Understand a balanced government budget as a macroeconomic objective and distinguish between deficit/surplus goals over the cycle.
Understand protection of the environment as a macroeconomic objective and links to sustainability and externalities.
Understand greater income equality as a macroeconomic objective and possible trade-offs with other objectives.
Distinguish between monetary policy and fiscal policy as demand-side policies.
Understand how changing interest rates (policy rate) affects AD components (C, I, net trade via exchange rates) and inflation/output in AD/AS terms.
Understand asset purchases to increase the money supply (quantitative easing): transmission mechanisms (liquidity, asset prices, yields, confidence) and potential limitations/risks.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fiscal policy instruments: spending and taxation
Sub_topics.description: Understand how government spending and taxation affect AD and the economy; relate to multiplier effects and AD/AS outcomes.
Distinguish between a government budget (fiscal) deficit and a budget surplus.
Distinguish between direct and indirect taxes and give examples of each.
Use AD/AS diagrams to illustrate demand-side policies (monetary and fiscal) and their effects on real output and price level.
Understand the role of the Bank of England in monetary policy, including the role and operation of the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Demand-side policies in Great Depression and 2008 crisis
Sub_topics.description: Demonstrate awareness of demand-side policies used during the Great Depression and the Global Financial Crisis (2008), including differing interpretations and policy responses in the US and UK.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Strengths and weaknesses of demand-side policies
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate strengths and weaknesses/limitations of demand-side policies (time lags, crowding out, inflation, debt, liquidity trap, distributional effects, confidence).
Distinguish between market-based and interventionist supply-side policy methods.
Analyse supply-side policies to increase incentives (e.g., tax reforms, welfare reforms) and likely impacts on productivity/LRAS and possible equity trade-offs.
Analyse supply-side policies to promote competition (e.g., deregulation, competition law) and impacts on efficiency, innovation and prices.
Analyse supply-side policies to reform the labour market (e.g., reducing union power, increasing flexibility, improving mobility) and effects on employment, wages and productivity.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Supply-side policies: skills and human capital
Sub_topics.description: Analyse supply-side policies to improve skills and quality of the labour force (education, training, apprenticeships) and impacts on productivity and long-run growth.
Analyse supply-side policies to improve infrastructure (transport, digital, energy) and impacts on productivity, costs and LRAS.
Use AD/AS diagrams to illustrate supply-side policies, typically via shifts in LRAS (and potentially SRAS) and resulting effects on output/price level.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Strengths and weaknesses of supply-side policies
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate strengths and weaknesses of supply-side policies (time lags, costs, uncertainty, distributional impacts, effectiveness depends on conditions).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Conflicts and trade-offs between macro objectives
Sub_topics.description: Analyse potential conflicts and trade-offs between macroeconomic objectives (e.g., growth vs inflation, equality vs incentives, environment vs growth, current account vs growth).
Understand the short-run Phillips curve and how it illustrates a potential trade-off between inflation and unemployment in the short run.
Analyse potential policy conflicts and trade-offs (e.g., fiscal tightening vs growth, interest rate rises vs unemployment, exchange rate policy vs inflation) and evaluate policy mixes.

Topics.Strand: Theme 3: Business behaviour and the labour market

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why some firms stay small vs grow
Sub_topics.description: Analyse reasons why some firms remain small and why others grow (e.g., market size, access to finance, entrepreneurship, risk preferences, regulation, economies of scale).
Understand the significance of separation of ownership from control in large firms and the principal–agent problem (conflicts between shareholders and managers).
Distinguish between public sector and private sector organisations and implications for objectives/constraints.
Distinguish between profit and not-for-profit organisations and explain how objectives and behaviour may differ.
Understand organic growth (internal growth) as a method of business expansion.
Understand vertical integration as growth by merging with firms at different stages of production; distinguish forward vs backward vertical integration.
Understand horizontal integration as growth by merging with firms at the same stage of production within the same industry.
Understand conglomerate integration as growth by merging with firms in different/unrelated industries (diversification).
Evaluate advantages and disadvantages of organic growth (control, culture, risk, speed, economies of scale).
Evaluate advantages and disadvantages of vertical integration (secure supplies/outlets, reduce costs, market power vs management complexity, regulatory issues).
Evaluate advantages and disadvantages of horizontal integration (economies of scale, market share, monopoly power vs diseconomies, integration problems, regulation).
Evaluate advantages and disadvantages of conglomerate integration (risk spreading, diversification vs lack of focus, diseconomies, agency problems).
Analyse constraints on business growth: size of market, access to finance, owner objectives, and regulation.
Analyse reasons for demergers (e.g., focus on core activities, unlocking shareholder value, reducing diseconomies, regulatory pressures).
Analyse impact of demergers on businesses, workers and consumers (efficiency, employment, prices, choice, innovation).

Topics.Strand: Theme 3: Business behaviour and the labour market

Sub_topics.description: Understand profit maximisation as a business objective and reasons firms may pursue it; relate to economic models of firm behaviour.
Understand revenue maximisation as a business objective and reasons it may be pursued (e.g., managerial motives, market share).
Understand sales maximisation as a business objective and reasons it may be pursued (e.g., growth, market presence, bonuses).
Understand satisficing as a business objective (aiming for satisfactory rather than maximum outcomes), including links to uncertainty and principal–agent issues.

Use diagrams and formulae to illustrate profit maximisation, revenue maximisation and sales maximisation (e.g., MR=MC for profit max; TR maximisation at MR=0; sales maximisation subject to profit constraint).

Topics.Strand: Theme 3: Business behaviour and the labour market

Sub_topics.description: Use formulae to calculate and understand relationships between total revenue (TR), average revenue (AR) and marginal revenue (MR); interpret in price/output terms.
Use price elasticity of demand (PED) to analyse revenue: link PED to TR/AR/MR and perform required calculations (including how MR relates to PED and when TR rises/falls with price changes).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cost concepts (TC, TFC, TVC, AC, AFC, AVC, MC)
Sub_topics.description: Use formulae to calculate and understand relationships between total cost (TC), total fixed cost (TFC), total variable cost (TVC), average (total) cost (AC/ATC), average fixed cost (AFC), average variable cost (AVC), and marginal cost (MC).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Diminishing marginal productivity and SR cost curves
Sub_topics.description: Derive/interpret short-run cost curves from the assumption of diminishing marginal productivity (law of diminishing returns) and explain U-shapes of AVC/AC and rising MC.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Short-run vs long-run average cost curves
Sub_topics.description: Understand the relationship between short-run average cost (SRAC) curves and the long-run average cost (LRAC) curve (envelope), and implications for scale decisions.
Understand types of economies of scale and diseconomies of scale (e.g., technical, managerial, purchasing, financial, marketing; coordination/communication issues).
Understand minimum efficient scale (MES) as the output level where LRAC is minimised/near-minimised and its significance for market structure and entry barriers.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Internal vs external economies of scale
Sub_topics.description: Distinguish between internal economies of scale (within firm) and external economies of scale (industry/cluster-related).
Understand the condition for profit maximisation (e.g., MR=MC; and MC cuts MR from below) and apply in diagrams/numerical settings.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Normal profit, supernormal profit and losses
Sub_topics.description: Distinguish between normal profit, supernormal (abnormal) profit and losses; relate to explicit and implicit costs and long-run equilibrium.
Use diagrammatic analysis to understand short-run and long-run shut-down points (e.g., SR shutdown when P<AVC; LR when P<AC) and implications for firm decisions.

Topics.Strand: Theme 3: Business behaviour and the labour market

Sub_topics.description: Understand allocative efficiency (P=MC; resources allocated to maximise welfare) and how it may differ across market structures.
Understand productive efficiency (production at lowest average cost; producing on the AC minimum) and how it may differ across market structures.
Understand dynamic efficiency (innovation, R&D, new products/processes over time) and links to competition/market power.
Understand X-inefficiency as organisational slack/cost inefficiency due to lack of competitive pressure; apply to monopoly/oligopoly contexts.
Analyse efficiency/inefficiency (allocative, productive, dynamic, X-inefficiency) in different market structures and evaluate trade-offs.
Understand characteristics of perfect competition (many firms, homogeneous product, perfect information, no barriers, price takers).
Explain and illustrate profit-maximising equilibrium in perfect competition in the short run and long run, including normal profit in LR equilibrium.
Use diagrammatic analysis for perfect competition (AR=MR=P, MC, AC) to show output, price, and profit/loss in SR and LR.
Understand characteristics of monopolistically competitive markets (many firms, product differentiation, some price-setting power, low barriers).
Explain and illustrate profit-maximising equilibrium in monopolistic competition in SR and LR (including LR normal profit with excess capacity).
Use diagrammatic analysis for monopolistic competition (downward AR, MR, MC, AC) in SR and LR.
Understand characteristics of oligopoly: high barriers to entry/exit, high concentration ratio, interdependence of firms, and product differentiation.
Calculate n-firm concentration ratios and analyse their significance for market power/competition in an industry.
Analyse reasons for collusive and non-collusive behaviour in oligopoly (incentives to cooperate vs temptations to cheat; role of interdependence and repeated interaction).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Overt vs tacit collusion (cartels, price leadership)
Sub_topics.description: Distinguish overt collusion (cartels) and tacit collusion; understand price leadership as a form of tacit coordination and implications for prices/output.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Game theory: prisoner's dilemma (2 firm/2 outcome)
Sub_topics.description: Use simple game theory: understand and apply the prisoner’s dilemma in a simple two-firm/two-outcome model to explain incentives for non-collusion and outcomes.
Understand price wars in oligopoly, why they occur, and impacts on firms/consumers (profits, market share, possible predation).
Understand predatory pricing as a strategy to drive rivals out or deter entry; evaluate feasibility and consequences (short-run losses vs long-run market power).
Understand limit pricing as setting price low enough to deter entry; analyse conditions and implications for welfare and competition.
Understand types of non-price competition (advertising, branding, product quality/features, customer service, loyalty schemes) and why they are used in oligopoly.
Understand characteristics of monopoly (single dominant firm, high barriers, price maker) and sources of monopoly power.
Explain monopoly profit-maximising equilibrium (MR=MC) and resulting price/output versus competitive outcomes.
Use diagrammatic analysis for monopoly (AR, MR, MC, AC) to show price, output, and profits; identify welfare loss (deadweight loss) where relevant.

Understand third-degree price discrimination: necessary conditions (market power, separable markets, different PED, no resale/arbitrage) and use diagrams to show different prices/outputs in different markets.
Evaluate costs and benefits of third-degree price discrimination to consumers and producers (consumer surplus redistribution, output changes, welfare implications).
Evaluate costs and benefits of monopoly for firms, consumers, employees and suppliers (prices, choice, efficiency, innovation, wages, buyer power).
Understand natural monopoly (declining LRAC over relevant range, large fixed costs, network industries) and implications for regulation and efficiency.

Understand monopsony as a market with a single (or dominant) buyer; explain conditions under which a monopsony operates (e.g., labour market with one major employer) and how it can influence price/wages.
Evaluate costs and benefits of a monopsony to firms, consumers, employees and suppliers (lower input prices/wages, employment effects, possible efficiency outcomes).
Understand characteristics of contestable markets (ease of entry/exit, low sunk costs, threat of hit-and-run entry).
Analyse implications of contestable markets for firm behaviour (limit pricing, higher efficiency, lower supernormal profits even with few firms).
Understand types of barriers to entry and exit (legal, technological, branding, economies of scale, access to resources, predation, switching costs).
Understand sunk costs and how they affect the degree of contestability; relate sunk costs to entry/exit decisions and market outcomes.

Topics.Strand: Theme 3: Business behaviour and the labour market

Sub_topics.description: Analyse factors influencing demand for labour (e.g., demand for product, labour productivity, wage rate, substitutability with capital/technology).
Understand labour demand as a derived demand (depends on demand for the goods/services labour helps produce).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Determinants of labour supply to an occupation
Sub_topics.description: Analyse factors influencing supply of labour to a particular occupation (e.g., wage rates, working conditions, training requirements, mobility, demographics, preferences).
Understand market failure in labour markets arising from geographical and occupational mobility and immobility of labour; analyse causes and consequences.
Use diagrams to analyse labour market equilibrium: wage rate and employment level where labour demand equals labour supply.
Demonstrate understanding of current labour market issues (e.g., minimum wage debates, gig economy, inequality, shortages), applying labour market theory.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Government intervention: maximum and minimum wages
Sub_topics.description: Analyse government intervention in labour markets through maximum wages and minimum wages; use diagrams to show effects on employment, unemployment, and wages.
Understand public sector wage setting as a form of intervention and analyse impacts on labour allocation, fiscal position and service quality.
Analyse policies to tackle labour market immobility (e.g., retraining, relocation support, information, housing policies) and evaluate effectiveness.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Elasticities of labour demand and supply
Sub_topics.description: Understand significance of elasticity of demand for labour and elasticity of supply of labour for wage and employment outcomes and for the impacts of interventions (e.g., minimum wage incidence).

Topics.Strand: Theme 3: Business behaviour and the labour market

Sub_topics.description: Understand government intervention to control mergers (competition policy): reasons (market power, consumer welfare) and possible remedies/approaches.
Analyse price regulation of monopolies (e.g., price caps) and effects on prices, profits, efficiency and consumers.
Analyse profit regulation (limiting returns) and evaluate impacts on investment, efficiency and consumer outcomes.
Understand use of quality standards in regulating monopolies; evaluate impacts on costs, service quality and welfare.
Understand performance targets as regulatory tools for monopolies and evaluate effectiveness and incentives created.
Analyse policies to enhance competition/contestability through promotion of small business (e.g., grants, reduced barriers) and effects on market outcomes.
Analyse deregulation as a method to promote competition and contestability; evaluate benefits and risks (e.g., safety, externalities).
Understand competitive tendering for government contracts as a method to increase competition; evaluate effects on cost, quality and efficiency.
Understand privatisation as a policy to promote competition/efficiency; evaluate impacts on prices, quality, investment, equity and market power.
Understand interventions to protect suppliers and employees by restricting monopsony power of firms; evaluate impacts on wages, employment, and efficiency.
Understand nationalisation as intervention to protect suppliers/employees or address monopoly/market failure; evaluate likely impacts on efficiency, investment and welfare.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Intervention impacts on prices and profits
Sub_topics.description: Analyse impact of government intervention on prices and profits in different market structures; use appropriate diagrams/evidence.
Analyse impact of intervention on allocative/productive/dynamic efficiency and X-inefficiency; evaluate trade-offs.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Intervention impacts on quality and choice
Sub_topics.description: Analyse impact of intervention on product/service quality and consumer choice; evaluate outcomes for stakeholders.
Understand regulatory capture as a limit to government intervention (regulators influenced by regulated firms) and implications for policy effectiveness.
Understand asymmetric information between regulators and firms/markets as a limit to intervention; evaluate how it can lead to ineffective regulation or unintended outcomes.

Topics.Strand: Theme 4: A global perspective

Sub_topics.description: Understand characteristics of globalisation (increased international integration of markets, trade, finance, migration, information and global supply chains).
Analyse factors contributing to globalisation over the last 50 years (e.g., technology, transport costs, trade liberalisation, TNCs, institutions, communication).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impacts of globalisation and global companies
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate impacts of globalisation and global companies (TNCs) on countries, governments, producers/consumers, workers and the environment (winners/losers, tax competition, labour standards, externalities).
Understand and apply absolute advantage and comparative advantage using numerical and diagrammatic examples; include assumptions and limitations of comparative advantage theory.
Evaluate advantages and disadvantages of specialisation and trade in an international context (efficiency gains vs dependency, adjustment costs, inequality, environment).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Determinants of trade patterns and changing trade flows
Sub_topics.description: Analyse factors influencing patterns of trade and changes in trade flows: comparative advantage, impact of emerging economies, growth of trading blocs/bilateral agreements, and changes in relative exchange rates.
Calculate terms of trade (ToT) (e.g., index of export prices / index of import prices ×100) and interpret changes.
Analyse factors influencing a country’s terms of trade (e.g., exchange rates, global demand, commodity prices, inflation differentials, productivity/quality).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impacts of terms of trade changes
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate impact of changes in a country’s terms of trade on living standards, current account, growth and inflation; consider elasticities and dependency on imports/exports.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Trading blocs: free trade areas, customs unions, common markets
Sub_topics.description: Understand types of trading blocs/regional trade agreements: free trade areas, customs unions and common markets; explain key features and differences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Monetary unions and Eurozone success conditions
Sub_topics.description: Understand monetary unions and conditions necessary for their success, with particular reference to the Eurozone (e.g., convergence, labour mobility, fiscal transfers, similar cycles).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Costs and benefits of regional trade agreements
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate costs and benefits of regional trade agreements (trade creation/diversion, economies of scale, competition, sovereignty issues).
Understand the role of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) in trade liberalisation, rule-setting and dispute settlement.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Conflicts between regional agreements and WTO
Sub_topics.description: Analyse possible conflicts between regional trade agreements and the WTO (e.g., discrimination, rules, enforcement).
Analyse reasons for restrictions on free trade (e.g., infant industry, strategic industries, protect jobs, anti-dumping, revenue, environmental/labour standards).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Protectionism tools: tariffs, quotas, subsidies, non-tariff barriers
Sub_topics.description: Understand types of trade restrictions: tariffs, quotas, subsidies to domestic producers, and non-tariff barriers; explain how each affects price/quantity/trade flows.
Evaluate impacts of protectionist policies on consumers, producers, governments, living standards and equality (domestic and global), including retaliation risks.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Balance of payments components (current, capital, financial)
Sub_topics.description: Understand components of the balance of payments: the current account, the capital account and the financial account.
Analyse causes of current account deficits and surpluses (competitiveness, exchange rates, income, savings/investment balance, commodity dependence).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Policies to reduce current account imbalance
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate measures to reduce a country’s current account imbalance (e.g., devaluation, supply-side competitiveness, demand management, protectionism) and consider constraints/trade-offs.
Understand significance of global trade imbalances (e.g., debt accumulation, global demand, exchange rate tensions, financial stability).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Exchange rate systems: floating, fixed, managed
Sub_topics.description: Distinguish exchange rate systems: floating, fixed and managed exchange rates; understand how each operates and policy implications.
Distinguish between revaluation (official increase under fixed/managed systems) and appreciation (market-driven increase under floating) of a currency.
Distinguish between devaluation (official decrease under fixed/managed systems) and depreciation (market-driven fall under floating) of a currency.
Analyse factors influencing floating exchange rates (e.g., interest rates, inflation expectations, current account, capital flows/FDI, speculation, confidence).
Understand government/central bank intervention in currency markets through foreign currency transactions and the use of interest rates; evaluate effectiveness and costs.
Understand competitive devaluation/depreciation and evaluate consequences (trade retaliation, inflation, ‘currency wars’).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Exchange rates and current account (Marshall–Lerner, J-curve)
Sub_topics.description: Analyse impact of exchange rate changes on the current account, referencing Marshall–Lerner condition and the J-curve effect; apply elasticities/time-lag reasoning.
Analyse how exchange rate changes affect economic growth and employment/unemployment through net exports, AD and competitiveness.
Analyse how exchange rate changes affect inflation (import prices, cost-push pressures, AD effects).
Analyse how exchange rate changes affect foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows/outflows and multinational investment decisions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Competitiveness measure: relative unit labour costs
Sub_topics.description: Understand relative unit labour costs as a measure of international competitiveness and how they are influenced by wages and productivity.
Understand relative export prices as a measure of international competitiveness, including the role of exchange rates and domestic costs.
Analyse factors influencing international competitiveness (productivity, costs, innovation, infrastructure, skills, exchange rates, regulation, quality/branding).

Evaluate significance of international competitiveness: benefits of being competitive (exports, growth, jobs, current account) and problems of being uncompetitive (deficits, deindustrialisation, unemployment).

Topics.Strand: Theme 4: A global perspective

Sub_topics.description: Distinguish between absolute poverty and relative poverty and apply to international and within-country comparisons.
Understand measures of absolute poverty and relative poverty (e.g., poverty lines, % below median income) and interpret data.
Analyse causes of changes in absolute poverty and relative poverty (growth, distribution, conflict, policy, demographics).
Distinguish between wealth inequality and income inequality; explain why wealth inequality can differ from income inequality.
Construct/interpret Lorenz curves using diagrammatic analysis to show income distribution and inequality changes.
Understand and interpret the Gini coefficient as a numerical measure of income inequality derived from the Lorenz curve; compare across countries/time.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Causes of inequality within and between countries
Sub_topics.description: Analyse causes of income and wealth inequality within countries and between countries (education/skills, technology, globalisation, labour market institutions, inheritance, tax/benefits, property ownership).
Analyse impact of economic change and development on inequality (e.g., Kuznets-type effects, structural change, policy context).
Evaluate significance of capitalism for inequality, considering how market-based income distribution, returns to capital, and policy choices may affect inequality outcomes.

Topics.Strand: Theme 4: A global perspective

Sub_topics.description: Understand the three dimensions of the Human Development Index (HDI)—education, health, and living standards—and how they are measured and combined into an index.
Evaluate advantages and limitations of using HDI to compare development between countries and over time (multi-dimensional vs data/weighting/inequality limitations).
Understand other indicators of development beyond HDI (e.g., GDP per capita, poverty measures, literacy, life expectancy, access to clean water, inequality-adjusted measures).
Analyse how primary product dependency can affect growth and development (terms of trade volatility, low value-added, Dutch disease risks).
Analyse how volatility of commodity prices affects developing economies’ revenues, stability, investment and development outcomes.
Understand the savings gap using the Harrod–Domar model: how low savings/investment can constrain growth; link to capital accumulation.
Understand the foreign currency gap as a development constraint (insufficient foreign exchange to import capital goods/inputs needed for growth).
Analyse capital flight and how it constrains development (loss of domestic savings/tax base, reduced investment).
Analyse demographic factors affecting growth and development (dependency ratios, population growth, urbanisation, demographic dividend).
Analyse how debt levels and debt servicing can constrain growth and development (crowding out, austerity, default risk).
Analyse how limited access to credit/banking affects entrepreneurship, investment, consumption smoothing and development.
Analyse the role of infrastructure (transport, energy, water, telecoms) in supporting productivity, trade and development.
Analyse how education and skills (human capital) affect productivity, innovation, employability and development outcomes.
Analyse how absence of secure property rights can hinder investment, access to credit (collateral), and efficient resource allocation.
Analyse impact of non-economic factors on growth and development (e.g., governance, corruption, political stability, institutions, culture, geography, conflict).
Evaluate trade liberalisation as a market-oriented development strategy (comparative advantage gains vs adjustment costs, infant industry concerns).
Evaluate promotion of foreign direct investment (FDI) as a development strategy (capital/technology transfer vs profit repatriation, enclave effects).
Evaluate removal of government subsidies as a development strategy (efficiency/fiscal sustainability vs social impacts, poverty).
Evaluate floating exchange rate systems as a development strategy (automatic adjustment vs volatility, inflation risks).
Evaluate microfinance schemes as a development strategy (financial inclusion vs interest burdens, limited scale).
Evaluate privatisation as a development strategy (efficiency/FDI vs access/affordability, monopoly power, governance).
Evaluate interventionist strategies to develop human capital (education/health) and links to productivity and inclusive growth.
Evaluate protectionism as an interventionist development strategy (infant industry protection vs inefficiency, retaliation, higher prices).
Evaluate managed exchange rates as a development strategy (stability/competitiveness vs reserves needs, policy constraints).
Evaluate infrastructure development as an interventionist strategy (productivity gains vs financing, debt, governance).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Interventionist: joint ventures with global companies
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate promoting joint ventures with global companies (technology spillovers/local participation vs bargaining power, regulation challenges).
Evaluate buffer stock schemes to stabilise commodity prices/incomes (stabilisation benefits vs cost, storage, coordination problems).
Understand industrialisation as a development strategy with reference to the Lewis model (labour transfer from subsistence agriculture to industry) and evaluate implications.
Evaluate development of tourism as a growth/development strategy (foreign exchange/jobs vs seasonality, leakages, environmental/cultural impacts).
Evaluate development of primary industries as a strategy (resource-based growth vs dependency, volatility, low value-added).
Evaluate Fairtrade schemes as a development strategy (price stability/income support vs limited coverage, market distortions).
Evaluate aid as a development strategy (financing, humanitarian support) including limitations (dependency, governance, corruption, conditionality).
Evaluate debt relief as a development strategy (fiscal space vs moral hazard, conditionality, future borrowing constraints).
Demonstrate awareness of the role of international institutions in development, specifically the World Bank (loans, development projects, policy advice).
Demonstrate awareness of the role of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) (balance of payments support, conditionality, stabilisation programmes) in developing economies.
Demonstrate awareness of the role of non-government organisations (NGOs) in development (aid delivery, advocacy, health/education programmes) and potential strengths/limitations.

Topics.Strand: Theme 4: A global perspective

Sub_topics.description: Understand the role of financial markets in facilitating saving (channels for households/firms to store value and allocate funds).
Understand how financial markets/banking facilitate lending to businesses and individuals, supporting investment and consumption smoothing.
Understand how financial markets facilitate exchange of goods and services (payments systems, credit, liquidity).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Forward markets in currencies and commodities
Sub_topics.description: Understand how financial markets provide forward markets in currencies and commodities, enabling hedging against price/exchange-rate risk.
Understand how financial markets provide a market for equities (raising capital, share ownership, price discovery).
Analyse market failure in the financial sector due to asymmetric information (e.g., adverse selection, borrowers’ risk unknown) and consequences for credit allocation.
Analyse externalities in financial markets (systemic risk, contagion) where private actions create wider social costs/benefits.
Analyse moral hazard in the financial sector (risk-taking encouraged by insurance/expectation of bailouts) and implications for regulation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Financial sector failure: speculation and bubbles
Sub_topics.description: Analyse how speculation can contribute to asset price bubbles and financial instability; understand boom-bust dynamics in financial markets.
Understand market rigging/manipulation in financial markets (e.g., collusion, benchmark manipulation) as a source of market failure and loss of trust/efficiency.
Understand central banks’ function in implementing monetary policy (setting policy rates, managing money supply/QE).
Understand central banks as banker to the government (government accounts, debt management support, issuing currency).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Central banks: lender of last resort
Sub_topics.description: Understand central banks as banker to the banks and lender of last resort, providing liquidity to maintain financial stability.
Understand the role of central banks in regulation/supervision of the banking industry and promoting financial stability.

Topics.Strand: Theme 4: A global perspective
Topics.Topic_name: Role of the state in the macroeconomy

Sub_topics.description: Distinguish between capital expenditure, current expenditure and transfer payments and apply to fiscal analysis.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changing size/composition of public expenditure (global context)
Sub_topics.description: Analyse reasons for changing size and composition of public expenditure in a global context (e.g., ageing populations, welfare state, defence, recessions, political priorities).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Public spending share of GDP: productivity and growth
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate significance of differing public expenditure levels (as % of GDP) for productivity and economic growth (public investment, human capital vs inefficiency).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Public spending share of GDP: living standards
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate significance of public spending levels for living standards (public services, redistribution, merit goods).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Public spending share of GDP: crowding out
Sub_topics.description: Analyse how high public spending/borrowing may lead to crowding out of private sector activity (interest rates, resource competition) and evaluate conditions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Public spending share of GDP: taxation and incentives
Sub_topics.description: Analyse how higher public expenditure may require higher taxation and consider impacts on incentives, efficiency and behaviour.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Public spending share of GDP: equality
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate how public expenditure levels and composition affect equality (redistribution, access to services) and poverty outcomes.
Distinguish between progressive, proportional and regressive taxes; apply to examples and distributional effects.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Tax changes and incentives to work
Sub_topics.description: Analyse economic effects of changes in direct and indirect tax rates on incentives to work (labour supply, substitution/income effects).
Understand and apply the Laffer curve to analyse how tax rate changes may affect tax revenues, considering incentives and avoidance/evasion.
Analyse how changes in direct and indirect tax rates affect income distribution and inequality (incidence, progressivity).
Analyse how tax rate changes affect real output and employment (AD effects, incentives, supply-side impacts).
Analyse how changes in tax rates affect the price level (e.g., indirect taxes as cost-push; demand effects).
Analyse how tax changes can affect the trade balance (via demand for imports, competitiveness, exchange rate channels).
Analyse how tax rate changes can affect foreign direct investment (FDI) flows (after-tax returns, tax competition).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Automatic stabilisers vs discretionary fiscal policy
Sub_topics.description: Distinguish between automatic stabilisers and discretionary fiscal policy; explain how each affects the economy over the cycle.
Distinguish between a fiscal deficit (flow) and the national debt (stock).
Distinguish between structural and cyclical deficits and explain how they relate to the output gap and trend growth.
Analyse factors influencing the size of fiscal deficits (economic cycle, discretionary policy, demographics, interest costs).
Analyse factors influencing the size of national debts (accumulated deficits, growth, interest rates, one-off shocks, exchange rates if foreign currency debt).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Significance of fiscal deficits and national debt
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate significance of the size of fiscal deficits and national debts (sustainability, confidence, crowding out, intergenerational fairness, policy constraints).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Global macro policy toolkit and impacts
Sub_topics.description: Analyse the use of fiscal policy, monetary policy, exchange rate policy, supply-side policies and direct controls in different countries, including impacts of measures to reduce fiscal deficits/national debts, reduce poverty/inequality, change interest rates/money supply, and increase international competitiveness.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Macro policy responses to external shocks
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate use and impact of macroeconomic policies to respond to external shocks to the global economy (e.g., oil price shocks, financial crises, pandemics, geopolitical events).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Regulating TNCs: transfer pricing and limits
Sub_topics.description: Understand measures to control global companies’ operations, including regulation of transfer pricing; evaluate limits to government ability to control transnationals (mobility of capital, jurisdiction competition).
Analyse problems for policymakers due to inaccurate information (data uncertainty, measurement errors) affecting policy design and outcomes.
Analyse risks and uncertainties faced by policymakers (expectations, confidence, changing behaviour, unintended consequences) when applying macro policies.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Policy problems: external shocks beyond control
Sub_topics.description: Analyse the inability of policymakers to control external shocks and how this limits policy effectiveness; evaluate need for resilience and policy coordination.
